Southern Ohio Holding is proud to inform all interested parties that our company is complying with OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard (PSM), Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations 1910.119, and EPA's Risk Management Program Regulations (RMP), Title 40 CFR Part 68, In addition to other state and local codes applicable to our facility and process. We have undertaken this process to address with the risk involved with the storage, handling, and use of Anhydrous Ammonia in our Facility.

Our goal is to promote overall worker, public, and plant safety.

Southern Ohio Holding is located at 4585 Muhlhauser Road , Hamilton, Ohio 45011. We are a cold storage distribution warehouse with finished goods and refrigerated storage. The facility has an ammonia refrigeration engine room and miscellaneous utilities.

The refrigeration system required for our production process requires the submission of this Risk Management Plan. The refrigeration system contains 14,907 pounds of anhydrous ammonia. This exceeds the threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds outlined in Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program regulations.

Southern Ohio Holding has implemented policies and procedures to prevent the occurrence of, and minimize the consequences of, a significant release of Anhydrous Ammonia, as well as other hazardous substances , fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents. Overall these programs prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, and avoid property damage.

Our safety program aims to prevents accidents by it focusing on the rules, procedures, and practices that govern individual processes, activities, or pieces of equipment. These rules are detailed and improved as necessary. They are also communicated to, and accepted by, all employees at our facility. Our facility management believes in the importance of workplace safety and are empowered to enforce all of our company policies.

Southern Ohio Holding has organized the information and policies perta

ining to the process into a complete library consisting of five volumes.

Volume I of the PSM/RMP Library includes the following policies; 

Employee Participation Guidelines: This policy outlines the commitment by management and employees to establish a program for a successful (safe) program.

Process Safety Information : This includes information on the ammonia inventory at the facility, applicable codes, design standards, and information pertaining to the hazards of ammonia (referenced from the IIAR Ammonia Data Book).

Process Hazard Analysis Program: This program outlines a thorough, orderly, systematic approach for identifying, evaluating, and controlling potential hazards within a process involving potentially hazardous chemicals such as ammonia.

Employee Training Program: This program provides employees with a basic working knowledge of an ammonia refrigeration system. Areas covered are hazards of ammonia, understanding MSDS sheets, refrigeration cycles, normal system operation, and an individual's place in the emergency response plan.

Contractor Qualification Guidelines: This guideline has been established to verify that the contractors working in the facility are qualified to work on the system, trained in the hazards associated with their work, and made aware of the hazards present in the facility to the employees of the contractor.

Management of Change and Pre-Startup Safety Review Programs: These programs have been developed to monitor and provide a "check and balances" system to monitor changes in the facility and to verify that changes are safe and consistent with company policy.

Many more specific programs and policies ( Hot Work, Confined Space, Lockout / Tagout ) have been developed. For information on these programs and policies contact the Plant Safety Coordinator.

Volume II incorporates information on the specific system components of the production equipment (Compressors, Purgers, Vessels, Heat exchangers, Evaporators, Condensers, Pumps,

Piping systems,  Emergency ventilation system, Safety relief valves, and General safety). This information is used as a reference source for the operator to positively identify system components, ordering of spare parts, troubleshooting, etc.

Volume III incorporates a complete valve list, process and instrumentation diagrams, flow schematics, and other drawings pertinent to the production area equipment.

The valve list contains information on the type, port size, identifying number, use, location, model, manufacture, drawing reference, and normal operating position of each valve in the system.

Flow Schematics are included showing the entire system.

A Block Flow Diagram provides a brief overview of the system.

Drawings are included showing symbol and abbreviation descriptions. Plan views are included to allow the operator to physically locate equipment in the building.

Volume IV incorporates a complete set of Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for the ammonia refrigeration system equipment. These SOPs describe the proper steps for preparing components for start-up and starting components; monitoring normal operation of system components; shutting down components as part of normal operation; shutting down equipment for maintenance and restarting equipment after mantenance; shutting down equipment in emergency situations; and restarting equipment after an emergency situation shutdown. SOPs also discuss pumpout procedures for equipment. Also included as a part of each SOP are the Technical Operating Specifications (TOS) for the associated system component. This information includes consequences of deviation from standard operating procedures.

Volume V contains Operating and Maintenance Information for the ammonia refrigeration system equipment including manufacturer's information, spare parts list, maintenance procedures, and preventative maintenance procedures.

A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was completed on 8th day of November 2002.

DESCRIPTION OF THE REFRIGERATION SYSTEM

Southern Ohio Holding facility incorporates a standard two stage Evaporation and Compression Style Ammonia Refrigeration system. Ammonia vapor, High Stage Suction (HSS), from the Horizontal Recirculator (V-2) is routed to the suction inlet of three High Stage Compressor (HS-1 through HS-3).

At the High Stage Compressors (HS-1 through HS-3), ammonia vapor (HSS) is compressed to a super heated vapor (HSD). The super heated vapor (HSD) from the High Stage Compressors is routed from the engine room to the three Condensers (EC-1,EC-2A and EC-2B). At the Condensers the super heated vapor (HSD) rejects heat and converts to high pressure Condensed Liquid Drain (CD). The condenser accomplishes this by using a combinaton of air and water flow across ammonia coils. The condensers are equipped with Hydrostatic Safety Relief Valves which vent back into the system. Airflow is supplied to the condensers via fans internal to the condenser and water is supplied via condenser water pumps.

Water from the condenser sump is pumped via condenser water pumps to the Condensers (EC-1,EC2A and EC-2B). At the Condensers the water is sprayed via a spray header over the ammonia coils. Water is collected at the bottom of the Condenser in a sump pan where by gravity it drains back to the condenser water pump. From here it is recirculated back to the condensers. As the water level of the condenser sump lowers it trips a water Makeup Float which opens allowing makeup water to refill the condenser sump.

The Condensed Liquid Drain (CD) from the Condensers (EC-1, EC-2A and EC-2B) drains back to the High Pressure Receiver (V-1).

The High Pressure Receiver (V-1) is used as a storage vessel for High Pressure Liquid (HPL). As HPL is needed in the system, HPL is fe

d by pressure differential from the High Pressure Receiver to the Auto Purger (AP-1), several evaporators, and serves as liquid makeup to several vessels.

High Pressure Liquid (HPL) is fed to the Auto Purger (AP-1). Purged Gas (PUR) is piped from the purge point at each piece of equipment to the Auto Purger.  This system has fourteen purge points, the Condensers (EC-1, EC-2A and EC-2B) and the High Pressure Receiver (V-1). Each purge point consists of a solenoid valve with shut off valves on either side for isolation. Any non-condensables in the Vapor Stream are removed periodically by the  Auto Purger. The Auto Purger separates the Purged gas (PUR). It separates ammonia from the non-condensables by condensing the ammonia into a liquid. Any non-condensables are piped to a Water Bubbler to remove any traces of ammonia. Condensed Vapor (LSS) is piped back to the Low Temperature Horizontal Recirculator (V-4).

High Pressure Liquid (HPL) is fed by pressure differential from the High Pressure Receiver to 50 degree dock evaporators (EV-13 through EV-16). As the liquid passes through the evaporator it absorbs heat from the air, changing to a vapor. The vapor from the evaporators exits these evaporators through a HSS pressure regulator and is piped back to the High Temperature Recirculator (V-2).

High Pressure Liquid (HPL) is fed by pressure differential from the High Pressure Receiver to 50 degree packaging evaporator (EV-17). As the liquid passes through the evaporator it absorbs heat from the air, changing to a vapor. The vapor from the evaporators exits and is piped back to the High Temperature Recirculator (V-2).

High Pressure Liquid is also fed to the High Temperature Recirculator (V-2). The liquid is fed through a solenoid valve and associated isolation valves and into the High Tempersture  Recirculator (V-2). Liquid from the High Temperature Recirculator (V-2) is fed via recirculaton pumps (RP-1 and RP-2) to 24 degree cooler evaporators (EV-1 through EV-5) and ab

sorbs heat from the air, changing to a liquid/vapor mixture. The liquid/vapor mixture from the evaporators passes through a suction gas powered stop valve as it exits. The liquid/vapor mixture from these evaporators are piped back to the High Temperature Recirculator (V-2). The liquid is fed through a solenoid valve and associated isolation valves and into the High Temperature Recirculator (V-2).  Liquid from the High Temperature Recirculator (V-2) is fed via recirculation pumps (RP-1 and RP-2) to 24 degree cooler evaporators (EV-1 through EV-5) and absorbs heat from the air, changing to a liquid/vapor mixture.  The liquid/vapor mixture from evaporators passes through a suction gas powered stop valve as it exits. The liquid/vapor mixture from these evaporators are piped back to the High Temperature Recirculator (V-2).  Evaporators (EV-1 through EV-5) have the capability to swing to receive Low Temperature Recirculated liquid from the Low Temperature Recirculator V-4. Liquid from Low Temperature Recirculator (V-4) is fed via recirculation pumps (RP-4 and RP-5) to the 24 degree cooler evaporators (EV-1 through EV-5) and absorbs heat from the air, changing to a liquid/vapor mixture.  The liquid/vapor mixture from evaporators passes through a suction gas powered stop valve as it exits.  The liquid/vapor mixture from these evaporators are piped back to the Low Temperature Recirculator (V-4).

Liquid from the High Temperature Recirculator (V-2) is also fed via recirculation pumps (RP-1 and RP-2) to a 50 degree packaging evaporator (EV-18) a 50 degree storage evaporator (EV-19), and 50 degree staging evaporators (EV-20 and EV-21) and absorbs heat from the air, changing to a liquid/vapor mixture.  The liquid/vapor mixture from the evaporators passes through a suction regulator as it exits.  The liquid/vapor mixture from these evaporators are piped back to the High Temperature Recirculator (V-2).  High Temperature Recirculated Liquid (HTRL) is also fed to Low Temperature Rec

irculator (V-4) The liquid is fed through a solenoid valve and associated isolation valves and then into the Low Temperature Recirculator (V-4).  Low Temperature Recirculated Liquid is also pumped via refrigerant pumps (RP-4 or RP-5) to zero degree freezer evaporators (EV-6 through EV-10), a zero degree blast freezer evaporators (EV-22 through EV-25) and absorbs heat from the air, changing to a liquid/vapor mixture.  The liquid/vapor mixture from these evaporators are piped back to the Low Temperature Recirculator (V-4).

High Temperature Recirculated Liquid is also pumped from the High Temperature Recirculator during high level situations via transfer refigerant pump (RP-3) to the HPL header.

All evaporators are equipment with High Stage Discharge Piping for the hot gas defrosting of ammonia coils.


SUMMARY OF THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Southern Ohio Holding has had no recordable accidents in the past five years involving ammonia.

DESCRIPTION OF THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN

An Emergency Planning and Response Program has been established to allow for safe mitigation of any ammonia release.

CONCLUSION

Southern Ohio Holding is committed to continuous improvement of our polices, procedures, and facility.  It is the intention of Southern Ohio Holding to remain an industry leader.  New technology, training techniques, and equipment are continuously being added to our system.  

Among the improvements slated for completion in 2004 are additional emergency responder and ongoing operating training.
